It coincided with Graziani's advance.]] The '''Via della Vittoria''' was a military road between [[Bardia]] in [[Italian Libya]] and [[Sidi Barrani]] in western [[Egypt]]. == Characteristics == The "Via della Vittoria" ("''Victory Road''"), was a [[road]] built by [[Italy|Italian]] [[engineer]]s during [[World War II]], between June and December 1940. The road went from [[Sidi Barrani]], [[Egypt]], to the border of [[Italian Libya]] and connected to the [[Libyan Coastal Highway|Via Balbia]]. == History == The Italian Army invaded Egypt in summer 1940 and penetrated until Sidi Barrani. The need of communication in order to supply the Army forced the construction of this new road.<ref>[http://www.egyptstudycircle.org.uk/Articles/p280QC223.pdf The Italian Army initial attack on Egypt]</ref> {{Quote|''Proceeding in an orderly, colonial fashion, the Italian commander in Egypt, General Mario Berti, deployed the advanced units of his Army (1st and 2nd Libyan, 3 January Blackshirt, Cirene and Catanzaro Divisions, as well as Malettiâ€™s motorised brigade group) in a ring of strong-points around Sidi Barrani, and began work on extending the Via Balbia into Egypt..''.<ref>Edmund Hall. ''The Italian attack on Egypt'' p.281</ref>}} In fall 1940 Italian Marshal [[Rodolfo Graziani]] ordered his Army in western Egypt to complete this new coastal road extending the Via Balbia 60 miles inside Egypt, even in order to create an infrastructure for a planned Italian invasion of the [[Nile Delta]] in January/February 1941. But in December 1940 the new road was used by the [[United Kingdom|British]] forces during [[Operation Compass]]. In the next two years the road was damaged by the continuous changes in the [[front]] between [[Axis powers|Axis]] forces under [[Erwin Rommel]] and the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]]. == See also == * [[North African campaign]] ==Notes== <references/> {{Italian colonial empire}} {{coord missing|Egypt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Via Della Vittoria}} [[Category:Roads in Egypt]] [[Category:Roads in Libya]] [[Category:Italian fascist architecture]] [[Category:Libya in World War II]] [[Category:Italian Libya]] [[Category:Cyrenaica]] [[Category:Western Desert Campaign]] {{Egypt-road-stub}} {{Libya-stub}}
